arm_group.description: Patients in this arm will receive self-propelled balloon PEGJ tube.
Patients in this arm will receive the standard commercially availabel PEGJ tube.

brief_summary.textblock:
Our main hypothesis is that self-propelled Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrojejunostomy tube
      (PEG-J) that has a balloon on it's tip is associated with lower J-tube retrograde migration
      rate, and lower rates of short- and long-term complications when compared to standard PEGJ
      feeding tubes.

clinical_study.brief_title: Self-Propelled Versus Standard Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrojejunostomy(PEG-J); RCT

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Consecutive adult patients (18-80 years of age) with need for post-pyloric feeding
             (patients unable to eat due to stroke, intubated patients with respiratory failure,
             patients with acute pancreatitis, etc).

          -  Ability to give informed consent.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Unable to give informed consent

          -  Pregnant or breastfeeding women (all women of child-bearing age will undergo urine
             pregnancy testing)

          -  Acute gastrointestinal bleeding

          -  Coagulopathy defined by prothrombin time < 50% of control; PTT > 50 sec,  or INR >
             1.5), on chronic anticoagulation, or platelet count <50,000

          -  Inability to tolerate sedated upper endoscopy due to cardio-pulmonary instability or
             other contraindication to endoscopy

          -  Cirrhosis with portal hypertension, varices, and/or ascites

          -  Allergy to egg

clinical_study.official_title: Comparison Outcomes and Complications of Self-Propelled vs. Standard Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrojejunostomy (PEG-J); a Randomized Single Blind Clinical Trial

overall_official.affiliation: Johns Hopkins Hospital Department of Gastroenterology

primary_outcome.description: Tube migration will be assessed by X-ray at 4 weeks post-intervention.
primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of placement up to 4 weeks

reference.citation: Kim KJ, Victor D, Stein E, Valeshabad AK, Saxena P, Singh VK, Lennon AM, Clarke JO, Khashab MA. A novel ballooned-tip percutaneous endoscopic gastrojejunostomy tube: a pilot study. Gastrointest Endosc. 2013 Apr 24. doi:pii: S0016-5107(13)00219-8. 10.1016/j.gie.2013.03.005. [Epub ahead of print]

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Medicine; Director of Therapeutic Endoscopy

secondary_outcome.description: Patiens who will have retrograde PEG-J tube migration will get repeat endoscopy for PEG-J tube placement
secondary_outcome.measure: Repeat endoscopy for feeding tube placement due to retrograde tube migration

secondary_outcome.description: Determine tube patency which is defined as time period between tube placement and need for re-intervention.
Success of tube placement in the desired location as determined endoscopically.
Time required from introduction of the upper endoscope until placement of the feeding tube.
If repeate endocopy and tube placement are needed due to clogging or retrograde migration
secondary_outcome.measure: Time to repeat endoscopy for tube replacement

secondary_outcome.description: Scored by the endoscopist on a 10-point Visual Analogue Scale)

Patients` quality of life will be assessed using a specific scoring system for digestive diseases.4 The score is based on the results of a self-administered questionnaire using 36 items related to digestive symptoms and quality of life, including nausea, bloating, abdominal pain, regurgitation and appetite. Each item is rated from 0 to 4 (0=extremely severe, 1=severe, 2=moderate, 3=mild and 4=absent). The overall GIQLI score is calculated by adding the scores for each item and varies from 0 (worst quality of life possible with severe digestive symptoms) to 144 (optimal quality of life without symptoms). Patients will fill GIQLI at baseline and 1, 2 and 3 months after procedure.
secondary_outcome.measure: Gastrointestinal Quality of Life Index (GIQLI) score

secondary_outcome.description: Short-term complications will include stomal (Infection, erythema, bleeding, pain and secretion, etc) and tube (Clotting, dislocation, defect, aspiration, etc) complications detected in the first week.

Long-term complications will include stomal (Infection, erythema, bleeding, pain, secretion, abscess, etc) and tube (Clotting, dislocation, defect and aspiration, etc) complications detected more than one week after intervention.

Cost will be determined according to Medicare reimbursement of billed CPT codes. The cost of all related follow-up procedures will be included (e.g. cost of standard PEGJ in case of failed Self-propelled PEGJ feeding tube, cost of managing complications, cost of re-intervention in case of tube dysfunction, etc)

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Supportive Care
